discussion.content:
Answer D is correct

AnyConnect-EAP, also known as aggregate authentication, allows a Flex Server to authenticate the AnyConnect client via the Cisco proprietary AnyConnect-EAP method
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security/flexvpn/200555-FlexVPN-AnyConnect-IKEv2-Remote-Access.html

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. DMVPN spoke-to-spoke traffic works, but it passes through the hub, and never sends direct spoke-to-spoke traffic. Based on the tunnel interface configuration shown, what must be configured on the hub to solve the issue?

discussion.content: Either A or B, since C and D are still using the default port 443. We need to know the IP address in the diagram to select between A or B.
A or B, very clear 443 blocked, so C&D wrong.
For me A or B are the same. And they are using IPSEC which is not port 443... So i do not get which answer is the correct one. A and B are the same for me.
i think the picture is not matching the question
CAN anybody explain please

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which two conclusions should be drawn from the DMVPN phase 2 configuration? (Choose two.)

choices.D: EIGRP route redistribution is not allowed.
choices.C: EIGRP is used as the dynamic routing protocol.

discussion.content: I go for C and E. conclusion on what information is showed. DVMPN phase 2 information and the routing protocol

comments.content: Uses a special CEF “trick” to implement spoke2spoke tunnels. All spokes need to receive full routing information with next-hop unchanged (e.g. using no next-hop-self eigrp or OSPF broadcast network type).

discussion.content: A & C is the correct answer

Selected Answer: CE
A is definitely wrong. The command "no ip next-hop-self eigrp 100" is required so that hub doesn’t list itself as the next hops for the routing updates of the spoke.

Selected Answer: CE
It is spoke-to-spoke via hub (phase2)

Selected Answer: AC
Phase2, so Spokes communicate through Hub, next-hop self is needed

Selected Answer: CE
no ip next hop is required for spoke-to-spoke comms if EIRGP is used. Not A, not B (unrelated), not D (unrelated), so it is C.
As it is there, spoke-to-spoke comms is enbaled. --> E

Selected Answer: CE
The premise is that we are looking at a DMVPN phase 2 configuration. That means that spoke-to-spoke traffic should be allowed. Remember that phase 2 requires the "no ip next-hop-self" command with EIGRP

Selected Answer: AC
Pardon me, the correct answers are A and C. 
EIGRP is the routing protocol, and since there is no spoke2spoke communication we need the hub to be next-hop self.

Selected Answer: CD
C and D should be the correct answers. NHRP redirect is not in the configuration, so no spoke2spoke traffic is allowed.

comments.content: It's actually A and D. The next-hop self is required when there is no spoke2spoke communication.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
C and E are correct

Selected Answer: C
There is a syntax referance which the aaa authorization must reference the authentication method (in this case pre-share or psk), and the list. https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/ios-xml/ios/sec_conn_ike2vpn/configuration/15-2mt/sec-cfg-flex-serv.html#:~:text=User%20authorization%2D%2DUse%20the,Framed%2DIP%2DAddress%20attribute.
C.is the answer coz psk is being used so the authorization group under ikev4 profile should refer to it rather than certification method

Selected Answer: C
C. Seems correct since is using PSK instead of Cert

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The VPN tunnel between the FlexVPN spoke and FlexVPN hub 192.168.0.12 is failing. What should be done to correct this issue?

choices.A: Add the address 192.168.0.12 255.255.255.255 command to the keyring configuration.
choices.C: Add the aaa authorization group psk list Flex_AAA Flex_Auth command to the IKEv2 profile configuration.
choices.D: Add the tunnel mode gre ip command to the tunnel configuration.
choices.B: Add the match fvrf any command to the IKEv2 policy.
